articles.headline: Failed Solar Company’s Auction Draws Bargain Hunters
articles.snippet: Solyndra, the failed solar company that became a political flashpoint, is selling off its equipment, but how much the auction will bring in is uncertain.
articles.abstract: Solyndra, the failed solar company that became a political flashpoint, is selling off its equipment, but how much the auction will bring in is uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREMONT, Calif. — To some people, the bankruptcy of the solar-module maker Solyndra shows the folly of government trying to pick winners in technology markets. To others, the furor over its $535 million federal loan guarantee represents an attack on the solar industry and the Obama administration’s clean energy policies.

articles.headline: Time Warner Trims Its Excesses
articles.snippet: Time Warner wants to cut back its overhead, including office space, so that it can continue investing in its shows, movies and journalism.
articles.abstract: Time Warner wants to cut back its overhead, including office space, so that it can continue investing in its shows, movies and journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sprawling taupe-colored offices of Jeffrey L. Bewkes, Time Warner’s chairman and chief executive, overlook Central Park from the 11th floor of one of Manhattan’s most plum pieces of commercial real estate. Mr. Bewkes cannot wait to move out.

articles.headline: Dissenting, or Seeking Shelter? Homeless Stake a Claim at Protests
articles.snippet: From Los Angeles to Wall Street, homeless men and women have joined the protesters in large numbers, and divisions have arisen across the country about how much, if at all, to embrace them.
articles.abstract: From Los Angeles to Wall Street, homeless men and women have joined the protesters in large numbers, and divisions have arisen across the country about how much, if at all, to embrace them.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Robert Gaffney, who came here from Oklahoma 10 years ago, settled on a scrap of burlap the other day on a grassy hill outside City Hall, surveying the tents and crowd that make up Occupy Los Angeles. For many of his neighbors at City Hall Park, this is a center of protest and political grievance. For Mr. Gaffney, it is the latest piece of land that he calls home.

articles.headline: Cain Confronts Claim From ’90s of Sexual Harassment
articles.snippet: Herman Cain maintained that he had been falsely accused while chief of the National Restaurant Association.
articles.abstract: Herman Cain maintained that he had been falsely accused while chief of the National Restaurant Association.
articles.lead_paragraph: Herman Cain, a surprise leader in the Republican race for the presidency, acknowledged Monday that he was accused of sexual harassment while chief of the National Restaurant Association in the 1990s, but he denied wrongdoing in an episode that has consumed his rising candidacy.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Report Says New York Fed Didn’t Cut Deals on A.I.G.
articles.snippet: In paying the full amounts A.I.G. owed financial companies, the New York Fed disregarded the expectations of senior Fed officials in Washington.
articles.abstract: In paying the full amounts A.I.G. owed financial companies, the New York Fed disregarded the expectations of senior Fed officials in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The findings of a federal investigation released Monday raised new questions about the Federal Reserve Bank of New York’s handling of the 2008 bailout of American International Group.

articles.headline: Raucous Trial Is a Test of Haiti’s Legal System
articles.snippet: For all its quirks, the trial of 13 police officers on charges of murder, attempted murder or other crimes stemming from a prison massacre last year is remarkable given Haiti’s history.
articles.abstract: For all its quirks, the trial of 13 police officers on charges of murder, attempted murder or other crimes stemming from a prison massacre last year is remarkable given Haiti’s history.
articles.lead_paragraph: LES CAYES, Haiti — It is a legal spectacle unlike anything Haiti has seen: the government trying 13 of its own police officers — including high-ranking prison officials and riot squad members — on charges of murder, attempted murder or other crimes stemming from a prison massacre here last year.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Deborah Sontag

articles.headline: Greek Revolt on Bailout Vote May Oust Prime Minister
articles.snippet: An emergency cabinet meeting called by Prime Minister George Papandreou ended with the cabinet supporting him and endorsing a referendum on the bailout.
articles.abstract: An emergency cabinet meeting called by Prime Minister George Papandreou ended with the cabinet supporting him and endorsing a referendum on the bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The government of Prime Minister George Papandreou teetered on the verge of collapse on Tuesday, threatening Greece’s adherence to the terms of a new deal with its foreign lenders and plunging Europe into a fresh bout of financial turmoil.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: European Debt Crisis Tightens Its Chokehold on Global Markets
articles.snippet: The declines wiped out gains of last week after the Brussels deal, which initially led some investors to believe Europe was addressing the Greek problem.
articles.abstract: The declines wiped out gains of last week after the Brussels deal, which initially led some investors to believe Europe was addressing the Greek problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European debt crisis demonstrated again on Tuesday the chokehold it maintains on investors worldwide, as a surprise move by Greece to put the terms of its planned bailout to a public referendum battered global financial markets.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Christine Hauser
